The definition of insanity

over and over and expecting

Except it's not.

Twain, except we're not
quite sure where it came from.

And for a saying that's

it's terribly cliched

But we describe things

So what does it actually

What is insanity?

My friends Mitch and Greg

The Oxford dictionary
defines insanity

as the condition
of being insane,

unsoundness of mind as a
consequence of brain-disease,
madness, lunacy.

But technically, insanity
isn't a medical term,
it's a legal one.

It refers to someone's ability
to determine right from wrong

when they have
committed a crime.

In the US, you can plead not
guilty by reason of insanity.

If the defendant can prove
that at the time of the crime,

as a result of a severe
mental disease or defect,

the defendant was
unable to appreciate

the nature and quality or
the wrongfulness of his acts.

This legal definition
of insanity

can overlap with the medical
diagnosis of mental illnesses,

but they are not
interchangeable.

Describing people
as insane or crazy

isn't really fair to those who
suffer from mental disorders,
and yet we do it all the time.

We even describe other
things as insane.
Take Tesla's insane mode.

It's when one of their
cars powered by dual motors

with an output of 691
horsepower accelerates from zero

to 97 kilometers per
hour in 3.2 seconds.
It's pretty wild.

In this case, insane is
beyond what we consider normal

and we're more likely to
call non-human things insane,

like cars, or roller
coasters, or animals.

People have even
reported that their pets
suffer from mental disorders.

They've observed cats suffering
from obsessive compulsive

disorder, horses suffering
from anxiety disorders,

and dogs suffering from
post-traumatic stress disorder.

So does that make
these animals insane?

4% of adults in
